2241.subject: Name of the bhajan
2241.author: Dinadayadri dd
2241.body: Thank you so much for this lecture. Unfortunately, it is not clear from the recording which Narottama das Thakura’s bhajan you were speaking on. Neither does it include the recording of the bhajan, which is a great loss for all of us. Sometimes the bhajans are not included in the recordings of the uploaded lectures (as it was with “Ajna Tahal” both on 15 and 17 of April in Tokyo and Vladivostok), which undoubtedly brings us great pain. Please kindly consider including them in the recordings, if you can forgive me such a bold request. I personally pray that your chanting of Jaya Radha Madhava before lecture could also be included at least sometimes for all of us to relish. Please forgive my offenses.

2243.subject: Thank you for giving me the
2243.author: Dinadayadri dd
2243.body: Thank you for giving me the intelligence! I just found that it was all on your YouTube channel. Sorry!

2138.subject: Dear Guru Maharadg. Please
2138.author: Tilakini dd
2138.body: Dear Guru Maharadg. Please accept our humble obeisances and great gratitude for the fact, that you find the opportunity to pay attention to children. Thanks  to this, their pure children's hearts are already filled with the great Faith...Little Devananda (7 years old) said-"Tell Guru Maharaja, that he is the best ! It was the happiest day of my life!" Thank you, dear Guru Maharaj, for being the best.

2139.subject: Харе Кришна! Дорогая матаджи
2139.author: Игорь Анатольевич
2139.body:
Харе Кришна! Дорогая матаджи Тилакини д.д. примите мои смиренные поклоны. Спасибо Вам за Ваше глубокое и чистое сердце Вайшнави.

В.в.с. Индрануджа дас.​​

2050.subject: Happy Sri Krishna Janmastami
2050.author: ashutosh108
2050.body:
Happy Sri Krishna Janmastami !
Dear Guru Maharaj,
Please accept our humble obeisances on this auspicious day.
Please bestow your mercy on us so that we can serve you!
Haribol,
Your most insignificant servants
Acharyanidhi Das and Sharodviharini DD
Calgary, AB, Ca

title: January 6, 2016 - Boston, USA - BG 8.20 - English Only
body:
Bhagavad Gita As It Is - Chapter 8 verse 20

paras tasmāt tu bhāvo 'nyo
'vyakto 'vyaktāt sanātanaḥ
yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu
naśyatsu na vinaśyati

paraḥ—transcendental; tasmāt—from that; tu—but; bhāvaḥ—nature; anyaḥ—another; avyaktaḥ—unmanifest; avyaktāt—from the unmanifest; sanātanaḥ—eternal; yaḥ—that; saḥ—which; sarveṣu—all; bhūteṣu—manifestation; naśyatsu—being annihilated; na—never; vinaśyati—annihilated.

TRANSLATION
Yet there is another nature, which is eternal and is transcendental to this manifested and unmanifested matter. It is supreme and is never annihilated. When all in this world is annihilated, that part remains as it is.

PURPORT
Kṛṣṇa's superior spiritual energy is transcendental and eternal. It is beyond all the changes of material nature, which is manifest and annihilated during the days and nights of Brahmā. Kṛṣṇa's superior energy is completely opposite in quality to material nature. Superior and inferior nature are explained in the Seventh Chapter.
author: Niranjana Swami

1818.author: GopaLiladhara
1818.body:
Thank you for this lecture . You touched so many exemples of golden behavior of  great devotees whos life and activity will help us to become a devotees some day  or some life too.

Just hearing , meditating , chanting , hoping !

1820.subject: Why do we delay on some other
1820.author: Bhava-bhavini devi dasi
1820.body:
Why do we delay on some other life?
"Pure devotional service rendered to the Supreme Lord is spiritually so potent that simply by hearing about such transcendental service, by chanting its glories in response, by meditating on it, by respectfully and faithfully accepting it, or by praising the devotional service of others, even persons who hate the demigods and all other living beings can be immediately purified." SB 11.2.12
Inconvinient truth

1694.subject: *: need sloka
1694.author: ananda rupini dasi
1694.body:
*: need sloka

translation one more time:

So, before I begin I offer my oseisances to all the illustrious devotees present before me, and I beg your forgiveness for you sitting here, but I have been asked to sit here.  And, being bound by the reqest of those authorities who have requested me to do this, I am sitting here, but I know that all of you are fully more qualified to speak on this topic than I am.  Therefore, I beg for your blessings that I may say something relevant.  *haribol, haribol, haribol* Spaceba.  There's an important point, there are many imortant points made in this verse. First, I would like to read just very shortly something Çréla Prabhupäda had written previously in this chapter about his definition of a seperatist, because that is also used in this verse of who is a seperatist. This verse says that, "one who offers Me respect, but is envious of the bodies of others, is therefore a separatist." and Prabhupäda says here,
"The word seperatist must be understood carefully. The Sanskrit words in this connection are bhinna-dåk and påthag-bhävaù. A separatist is one who sees his interest as separate from that of the Supreme Lord. Mixed devotees, or devotees in the modes of passion and ignorance, think that the interest of the Supreme Lord is supplying the orders of the devotee; the interest of such devotees is to draw from the Lord as much as possible for their sense gratification. This is the separatist mentality. Actually, pure devotion is explained in the previous chapter: the mind of the Supreme Lord and the mind of the devotee should be dovetailed. A devotee should not wish anything but to execute the desire of the Supreme. That is oneness. When the devotee has an interest or will different from the interest of the Supreme Lord, his mentality is that of a separatist."
So, we get a borader perspective of who is a separatist in this definition by Çréla Prabhupäda. Generally we think of a separatist as somebody who is not a part of the majority, has a separate interest.  "Oh he's a separatist.  He's not interested in what the majorty is interested in. He has is own personal ambitions," but, by this defintion given by Çréla Prabhupäda, and it's here also in this verse, a separatist is much broader than that.  A separatist is anyone who has an interest separate from the interest of the Lord.  And actually, we can actually say that practically speaking, the entire material world consists of seperatists, because the majority of living entites are serving somewhere else in relationship to the Supreme Lord. In fact, Çréla Prabhupäda makes an interesting point in one verse of the fifth canto of the Çrémad-Bhägavatam. It's a prayer by Prahläda Mahäräja where he prays, "may there be all auspiciousness throughout the universe, and may all envious persons  become pacified. May all living entites become calm by rendering Devotional Service to the Lord, for only then will they be able to think of the welfare of others. Therefore, let us all render service to the Supreme Lord and become absorbed in thoughts of Him."  The words that are used in this verse are "khalah-prasidatam" And when Prahläda Mahäräja was offering this prayer to Lord Nåsiàhadeva, he was praying for all envious living beings to become pacified. And in the word for word translation Çréla Prabhupäda gives a definition of the word khala which means envious, and he puts in parenthesis "almost everyone."  It's right there in Bhägavatam, fifth canto, ninteenth chapter, ninth verse, eighteenth chapter. 5.18.9. So almost everyone has some element of envy still within their heart, otherwise, why would they be here?  And according to this verse that is one offers respect to the Lord but is envious of others, therefore he is a separatist.  So really it puts a whole new deifinition of the meaning of separatist, when we see everything from Kåñëa's perspective. Or from the perspective of Kåñëa's pure devotees that one should not make distinctions between the different bodies of living beings.
vidyä-vinaya-sampanne
brähmaëe gavi hastini
çuni caiva çva-päke ca
paëòitäù sama-darçinaù
The humble sage, by virtue of true wisdom, see with equal vision the gentle and learned brähmaëa, the elephant, the dog and even the dog-eater.
And what is this equal vision?  The equal vision is to actually see how the Supersoul, the Lord within the heart, is providing the living entities a particular body according to their karma. An example is given.  It's just like the rain when it falls.  When the rain falls, all the different seeds in the ground they grow up.  So the seeds represent different bodies.  They may be a little tiny weed that grows, may be a huge tree that grows.  All these different bodies grow up by the one rain fall. In the same way, the Supersoul who is in the heart of all being, he inspires different living entities to accept bodies according to their karma.  And therefore, one who actually sees with equal vision should be very careful to not make distinctions between these different bodies.  Lord Caitanya himself when he was speaking to Sanätana Goswami, emphasized this point.  He said that when Sanätana Goswami was falling before the Lord asking, "my body is bad, you shouldn't touch it."  Because he had sores all over his body.  And Lord Caitanya corrected him and saying actually "no, you shouldn't be thinking like that," he said that, "anything that is not conceived in relationship with Kåñëa is understood to be illusion, and none of the illusions in this world, whether that are conceived in the mind, or spoken by words, are factual, and since illusions are not factual, one should be very careful to not make distinctions between what is good and what is bad." And when we speak of the Supreme Personality of Godhead, such speculations do not, are not to be taken into consideration.  And then he says,
’dvaite’ bhadräbhadra-jïäna, saba—‘manodharma’
’ei bhäla, ei manda’,—ei saba ‘bhrama’
that he describes such a mentality, that in this world, such thoughts as good and bad, they're all mental speculation.  Therefore to say this is good this is bad, it's all a mistake. It's manodharma." What is manodharma?  It's the religion of the mind. That is mano-dharma, to say this is good, this is bad.  It's a mistake because on the transcendental platform there is no good and there is no bad.  One should not make distinctions, this is good body this is bad body.  Therefore, spiritual vision, which is being recommended here in this verse, and Prabhupäda says very clearly in the commentary what that spiritual vision is.  He says that a devotee's vision must be perfect.  He should ignore bodily distinctions, and he should see only the presence of the part and parcel of the Supreme Lord, and the Lord himself in his plenary expansion as Supersoul, because by seeing such bodily distinctions, and judging such bodily distinctions, this is a manifestation of the separatist mentality because one is seeing different than the position of the Supersoul, who makes no distinction. Samo 'haà sarva-bhüteñu na me dveñyo 'sti na priyaù. Kåñëa says " I'm equal to everyone, I'm not envious of anyone."  Viçvanäth Cakravärté Öhäkura says that's the perspective of the Supersoul. "And whoever is a friend to me, I am a friend to them," Kåñëa says.  This is a little, this is Kåñëa's relationship from a different platform than Supersoul, but from the platform of Supersoul, Kåñëa says that "I am equal to everyone and not envious of anyone."  So, as long as there is any trace of envy in the heart, one can potentially begin to see distinctions based upon external designations, and by rendering Devotional Service, it's how it's supposed to help us become free from designatons. 
Sarvopädhi-vinirmuktaà,
tat-paratvena nirmalam,
håñékeëa håñékeça-sevanaà bhaktir ucyate,
that one of the characteristics that comes from rendering devotional service in the interest of the Supreme Lord, is that one becomes freed from designations.  But the seperatist, according to Çréla Prabhupäda's definition, is somebody who has an interest that is different then the interest of the Supreme Lord.  That person is a separatist.  Just like, we can think of so many examples in Bhägavatam of persons who displayed a separatist mentality.  Prajäpati Dakña, he was sitting in his yajïa, and all the goverers of the universe were all present, and he accused Lord Çiva of being a separatist.  He said, "everybody else is respecting me, why didn't you get up?"  He was proud of his postion.  He thought " I have been appointed by Lord Brahmä to be the chief progenitor.  I'm the top person in this sacrifice."  Of course, he had many other bodily designations in his mind as well, that " Lord Çiva is my son in law, he should be offering me respect, he's married to my daughter."  Again he was seeing according to external designations. " I'm cheif progenitor, you're my son in law, get up and offer me respect!"
And he didn't.  So, what does he have the audacity to say?  He says to everybody, "All sages, all brahmins, all fire gods, everyone else assembled, please listen to the words very attentively to what I have to say about the manners of gentle persons. I don't speak out of ignorance or envy."  It's the first thing he says before he starts speaking, he says " I don't speak out of ignorance or envy," and I think of that example that Prabhupäda uses when somebody is in the house stealing, and then somebody says to the person in the house who's stealing, " who's in there?" And the person responds, " there's nobody in here stealing!"  So, same way Dakña is saying, " I'm not envious!"  It's the first thing he says, and he was convinced of it, that he's not envious.  He was blind.  Lord Çiva later explained to Sati, although .. he said although the qualities of wealth, education, austerity, beauty, youth and heritage are for the highly elevated, one who's proud of posessing them cannot appreciate the great qualities in great personalities because they become blind.  And he was trying to warn Sati " don't go, don't go, he's ..your father's going to.." cause she wanted to go back.  It's a long story, and I don't have enough time to tell the whole Dakña yajïa scene, but here is Lord Çiva who's fixed in constant meditation on the Lord, the Suspersoul within the heart.  He was the only one in the sacrifice who wasn't a separatist.  Although Dakña was thinking, " Oh, Çiva's a separatist because he didn't stand up and respect me because I'm the cheif person at this yajïa.  But it was lord Çiva who was fixed in meditation on the Supreme Lord, and didn't even become the least bit disturbed when all the cursing an countercursing began taking place.  He just was thinking, " look at all these foolish children, cursing and countercursing," and he just decided to get up and leave " I don't want to be there anyways with them, this is my exuse to go some place else." So that's the danger when one is envoius of the bodies of others.  One whos envious of the bodies of others as being explained here, they begin to think this is good this is bad, and they begin to make distinctions.  And the verse states that such persons can never attain peace of mind. As Kåñëa says "one who is not connected tothe supreme one can have neither a steady intelligence or a controlled mind, without which there is no possibility of peace.  how can there be any happiness without peace?" So Lord Çiva was connected to the Supreme, and therefore He was able to remain peaceful throughout all those disturbances, but Dakña could not have a peaceful mind because he was filled with envy. That is the symtpom of a person who's heart still has some envy, is that he can never be peaceful, and he can't think of the welfare of others.  That's what Prahläda Mahäräja was praying to Lord Nåsiàhadeva, "may there be good fortune throughout the whole universe. and may all envoius persons become pacified. May all living entities become calm by being engaged in devotional service, because only then will they actually be able to think of others welfare."  It's very difficult to think of others' welfare when one's heart is still filled with envy. So we may be thinking, after hearing all these examples that I've given like of Prajäpati Dakña and his envy of lord Çiva, or another separatist is Hiranyakasipu, he's a separatist, he was envious of Prahläda Mahäräja who was always fixed on thoughts of Kåñëa.  And we can think of so many examples of separatists who are envious of great Vaisnavas. And we may think, oh well thats ok I'll just be care ful, I'll be very careful to not be envious of great vaisnavas. I'll be very careful. If anybody's a great vaisnava I"ll just hold my tongue, I won't say anything, I'll try my best just to not say anything I'm thinking. But thats not what this verse is about.  This verse is about all living entities.  Not just great Vaisnavas. All living entities, because in every body there is a living entity and inthe heart of every body is a Supersoul, the Lord within the heart.  And there's a verse in which very nicely explains this point I'll read it.  Its a verse from Caitanya Bhägavata
vaisnava himsara .. adama pidakare visnupujiya .. dukhi mare... *
What to speak of being envious of Vaisnavas, if one causes pain to ordinary living entities, he is considered a fallen low class person.  Even after worshipping Lord visnu, if a person gives trouble to other living enties, his worship becomes fruitless, such a person suffers unlimited miseries. If he worships the supreme Lord Viñëu, but if he causes pain to other living entities, his worship becomes fruitless. Example given in another verse in Caitanya Bhägavata is like a person who washes the feet of the brahmin with one hand, and the other hand he hits the Brahmin over the head with a stick. Two very incompatible actions being done simultanioiusly worshipping the feet and then washing the feet and then hitting him over the head at same time with the other hand. And it explains that this is what it's like to worship Lord Viñëu, and to be envious of other living entites at the same time. two completely incompatible activities performed simultaneously and therefore the verse explains, such worship is useless. And this verse today says " one who offers me respect but is envious of others can never have a peaceful mind." Now that's suffering, thats really suffering. Never be able to have a peaceful mind.  Because the mind of an envious person is always thinking of how to cause harm to others. And it ususallly comes from pride. Çréla Bhaktisiddhänta Sarasvaté Öhäkura concludes or explains in his commentary to this verse/point.  He elaborates even further from Caitanya Bhägavata, if a person is knowingly or unknowingly envious of a Vaisnava, who is engaged in the nonduplicitous service of Lord Hari, his degregation is inevitable. Ok that we can all grasp. We know this. We've heard it before. Apart from this, if even persons claiming to be devotees of Viñëu are envious of ordinary living entities, and give various troubles to them, they are actually far away from devotional service to Viñëu and are not fit to be called human beings. Phew. Some one may think that "I am Vaisnava" but it says here that "not even fit to be called a human being."  "Their worship of Viñëu becomes the source of misery, those endowed with an absence of jiva-doya, or compassion for other living entities, and yet proudly consider themselves servants of Lord Viñëu, acheive the threefold miseries rather than the devotional service of the Lord.." Therefore, one should understand that to purposely or intentionally cause pain to any living being is actually an act of envy.  And one should learn how to see, as Çréla Prabhupäda explains, with the proper spiritual vision.  One who's sees all living entites as spiritual sparks in quality one with the Lord, is a true knower of things, what then can be illusion or anxiety for him?  Unless we learn this principle, we're separaists, and anyone who doesn't teach this understanding of spiritual vision is also guilty of being a separatist.  This is spiritual vision, and therefore one has to be very very careful to cultivate the proper spiritual vision.  As we explained in the beginning, although we may not be on the platform of Pure Devotional Service, we must aspire for that. We have to learn how to see and discriminate properly from the spiritual platform, and not from a platform of good and bad.  This is good this is bad. This is friend this is enemy. This is again, this is the same principles when hiranyajasipu tried to teach Prahläda Mahäräja about friends and enemies, Prahläda Mahäräja was not capable of comprehending it. A friend is somebody who serves my interest, and anyone who tries to step in the way of my interest is my enemy. This is the duality of the material world and unless we learn to transcend the reality with a spiritual vision, we'll have to suffer continuously the threefold miseries of life. This is the message which is being taught here in this verse of Çrémad-Bhägavatam, and there are so much more examples that are given in Çrémad-Bhägavatam to help illustrate this point, but we've run out of time, so thank you very much for tolerating me, Hare Kåñëa.

1695.subject: Requested sloka
1695.author: admin
1695.body:
vaisnava-himsara katha se thakuka dure
sahaja jivere ye adhama pida kare
visnu pujiya o ye prajara pida kare
puja o nisphale yaya, ara duhkhe mare

>>> Ref. CB Madhya-khanda 5.140-141

title: October 27, 2007 - Budapest - Bhaktivedanta College Lecture #2  - English/ Hungarian
body: Bhaktivedenta College is a fully accredited, four-year college, fully sponsored by the Hungarian Government. It is located directly in the center of Budapest in a very prestigious part of the city. More than one-hundred sixty students are enrolled in the college, some of whom are weekly attending classes and are taking courses on Bhagavad-gita, Srimad Bhagavatam, The Nectar of Devotion, The four Vedas, The Six Goswamis, Sanskrit, and many other subjects related to Gaudiya Vaisnavism. When the students complete their four years of study, they are given degrees in "Vaisnava Theology" which can then be used for further studies, positions, or simply as an additional degree for their own advancement in academic studies. All of the teachers of the college are full-time practitioners of Krsna consciousness and are fully certified to teach their respective courses. Most of the students are enrolled in correspondence courses, and once every two weeks, on Saturday, they attend a lecture at the college to review their studies from the previous two weeks. Approximately fifty percent of the correspondence students and those attending daily classes are comprised of members of the Budapest congregation and are in some way connected with devotees although not all of them are practitioners of Krsna consciousness. However the other fifty percent of the students have no connection with Krsna consciousness other than through their enrollment with the college. Many of them come simply out of interest in Eastern Theology and Eastern Traditions. Once every month, the college holds a "Bhakti Club" program which is voluntarily attended by the students. There is usually a guest speaker or sometimes one of the teacher's will speak on the subject of Bhakti Yoga from the Bhagavad-gita. Niranjana Swami's October 1st lecture at the Bhaktivedanta College was one such gathering. This lecture given on October 27th was attended by approximately 80-100 students, most of them coming for their once-every-two-week, review-study on the fourth chapter of Bhagavad-gita.
author: Niranjana Swami
